item.title: 2025 Year-End Review
item.description:
Note: This is a translation of my Chinese year-end review. I wrote it in Chinese because I wanted to express my thoughts more accurately. I’ve translated it into English using Sonnet 4.5 to share with more people. I hope you can understand and forgive any awkwardness in the translation.

Winter: Post-Interview Wait

After returning from Cancun, I spent weeks waiting for results from my December 18th interview. Amazon didn’t send the offer until January 7th—ironically, after two or three weeks of silence, I actually became more confident I’d gotten it, since rejections usually come much faster.

Getting an internship locked down in January was completely beyond what I’d expected before leaving China—I’d estimated it would take until March or April. I recorded a video about my Canadian internship search experience on Bilibili, and unexpectedly connected with quite a few like-minded people through it, which strengthened my determination to create and share more content going forward. The whole point of this master’s program was to find a job, so once that goal was achieved, I felt completely justified in coasting through my remaining courses. I spent the rest of my time researching crypto/investment-related topics and various tax-advantaged accounts and convoluted tax rules—basically figured out my risk tolerance through trial and error. I’ll probably need to dive deeper into this later. In February, out of sheer boredom, I took a trip to Toronto—it was freezing. But I was really impressed by the underground PATH system that connects almost all the office buildings. A friend I went with knew someone at Amazon Toronto who gave us a tour of the office. The rest of the semester until the end was pretty rough. Vancouver’s perpetually overcast weather and 5 PM sunsets made things quite depressing. Having read plenty of horror stories about Amazon online, I was also worried about landing in a toxic team (turned out to be completely unnecessary), so my mood wasn’t as relaxed as I’d expected.

item.title: AWS Intern Reflection: Takeaways Beyond Tech
item.description:
Summer really flew by. These four months at AWS Vancouver were honestly the most unforgettable and fulfilling summer of my life. Besides Vancouver’s amazing weather, the project I worked on brought me huge challenges and satisfaction, plus the whole team had such an awesome vibe - it was basically a top-tier internship experience.

This blog isn’t your typical technical post. I won’t (and can’t) discuss specific technical solutions. Instead, I want to focus on what I learned throughout the internship and the moments that inspired me - just sharing my thoughts as an intern facing a massive and complex engineering system.

item.title: Building a Simple AI Conversational Assistant with Langchain.js
item.description: For my final undergraduate professional course, Software Development Practicum, I was tasked with developing a virtual veterinary hospital learning system that required implementing an AI conversational assistant. The requirements were somewhat ambiguous. Considering that the other components consisted mainly of basic CRUD operations, my initial approach was to explore integrating these operations with an AI dialogue system capable of querying information about medications and clinical cases stored in the database.

Demo link: ECNU-2022Spring-DatabaseTermProject Group 4_Bilibili

About Login Information and Permission Display

Here, sessionStorage is used to store user information and permissions (ideally, they should be returned together as user information, but here they are stored separately). Subsequent access to the left Aside of the page can also be resolved based on the stored sessionStorage.

The sessionStorage property allows you to access a session Storage object. It is similar to localStorage, except that the data stored in localStorage has no expiration time set, while the data stored in sessionStorage is cleared when the page session ends. The page session lasts as long as the browser is open, and reloading or restoring the page retains the original page session. Opening a page in a new tab or window initializes a new session in the top-level browsing context, which is different from how session cookies work.

item.title: About me
item.description:
Hi, I’m James Liu (刘佳铭). I wrote random stuff at my blog .

Study

I was born and raised in Beijing, where I spent my primary, middle, and high school years all at the same school . Interestingly, my kindergarten was right next door—quite the convenient setup!

Feeling ready for a change, I moved to Shanghai for my undergraduate degree at East China Normal University , studying Software Engineering from 2020 to 2024. I also spent a year at UC Berkeley (2022–2023) and a few months at the University of Alberta (Winter 2024) as an RA. After living in three different countries, I’ve realized I’d love to settle on the West Coast—somewhere with sunsets and pleasant weather.
